column4: Hello. Everytime I log in my audio volume is set to 100%. How to avoid this? My alsa setup: http://paste.ubuntu.com/888204/
which desktop are you using?
Ubuntu default.
I think it’s Gnome. How to figure out?
try setting the volume, and then executing gnome-session-save
Thanks, I’ll try that.
No such command.
which ubuntu version?
I think the current 11.10. How to find out?
Has the command changed in 11.10?
give amixer a try, put "amixer -q set Master 3% unmute" into /etc/rc.local ( before exit 0)
The amixer command doesn’t even work when still logged in. The slider in the panel audio settings icon doesn’t move.
what does it give in the console?
No error. When opening alsamixer I can see the Master slider move. But when I move the slider for the (audible) audio volume in the panel no slider in alsamixer moves.
perhaps you use pulseaudio, try: "amixer -D hw:0 -q set Master 3% unmute"
That command moves the same Master slider in alsamixer.
it DOES move the slider with "amixer -q set Master 3% unmute" for me
Not here.
just wanted to point that out :)
It does move the master slider in alsamixer. But that doesn’t affect the audible audio volume.
dlentz: /etc/rc.local diesn’t seem to be an appropriate place because pulse runs as the user after logging in. Any idea where to put that command?
